aBtn.aText: One of the Jews crossing the street took the photo surreptitiously
An official German photographer took the picture
A local Polish citizen took the photo

question.qText: The photographer might have taken the picture for all the following purposes EXCEPT

aBtn.aText: to show that ghetto life was orderly and well controlled
to document all aspects of ghetto life
to use later for propaganda
to have a record of individual ghetto inmates
to reinforce Nazi stereotypes about Jews

question.qText: For whom and for what purpose did the Nazis erect the sign?

aBtn.aText: For the Jews, to show them where they lived and to keep out those who would do them harm.
For the German military to warn them against mixing with Jews.
For local German and Polish residents of Lodz traveling through the ghetto to warn them not to communicate with the Jews.

question.qText: Why does the sign call the barbed wire enclosed ghetto a ‘Jewish Residential Area?'

aBtn.aText: The Nazis wanted to convince the Jews that they were being protected rather than imprisoned
The Nazis cared about the Jews’ feelings and thought it sounded nicer than ‘ghetto’.
The Nazis made it sound benign so that the Polish and German civilians would not develop sympathy for the Jews.

question.qText: In terms of audience and message, the photo primarily was meant

aBtn.aText: to show German military and civil authorities how the ghetto was being administered
to show the German public how Jews were being treated in Poland
to show the Polish populace what life was like in Lodz under German occupation
to show Jews still living in Germany what they could expect when they were deported
tto show the rest of the world how humanely they were treating their Jewish captives.

question.qText: The photo most strongly represents the point of view of which of the following?

aBtn.aText: The Polish government
The ghetto’s Jewish council
The German military and civil administration of Lodz
The German and Polish residents of Lodz
The Jewish ghetto inhabitants
